channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: As Zelensky Deplores U.N. Inaction, West Turns Up Economic Pressure on Russia
item.description: “Now the world can see what Russia did in Bucha,” President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said of the slaughter of civilians, during a fiery speech to the U.N. Security Council in which he showed a graphic video of the aftermath.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Up-Close Ukraine Atrocity Photographs Touch a Global Nerve
item.description: The apparent execution of Ukrainian civilians by retreating Russian forces, their bodies strewn in streets and yards, has focused attention on what constitutes crimes in war.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tatyana Petrovna, 72, in the garden of a Bucha home where the bodies of three civilians lay on Monday.

item.title: For Macron, France’s Troubled Industries Hit Home
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron vowed an economic revival, but as he seeks re-election, a Potemkin factory in the town where he was raised shows just how hard that can be.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site of the Whirlpool plant in Amiens, France. Mr. Macron promised to save the factory, and his government poured millions in subsidies toward its reinvention.

item.title: Dead Lay Out in Bucha for Weeks, Refuting Russian Claim, Satellite Images Show
item.description: The images rebut Russia’s claim that the killing of civilians in Bucha, near Kyiv, took place after its soldiers had left town.
item.dc:creator: Malachy Browne, David Botti and Haley Willis

item.title: Some Ukrainian Refugees Are Returning Home, Despite the Risks
item.description: A growing number of families, convinced the war could last for years, have decided that facing danger at home is better than life as a refugee.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Homecoming: Mariia Seniuk, left, with her two daughters, arriving from Szczecin, Poland, at the main bus terminal in Lviv, Ukraine. “Home is home,” she said.

item.title: Darfur War Crimes Trial Begins in Hague
item.description: A brutal campaign in western Sudan left the world aghast. Two decades later, the first and only Darfur war crimes trial opened for a man accused of leading the terrifying janjaweed militia.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons and Isabella Kwai
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Ali Kushayb at the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Tuesday. He is charged with 31 counts of war crimes and crimes against humanity.

item.title: Jewish Man’s Death Near Paris Fuels Outrage on Election Eve
item.description: Newly surfaced video shows the man, who was hit by a tram in February, fleeing an assault. It has fueled suspicions of an antisemitic motive days before France’s presidential vote.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: The prosecutor in the case, Éric Mathais, said his office was questioning witnesses in the death of Jérémy Cohen but that it had not yet determined what had motivated the assault.

item.title: Canada to Require Tech Giants to Compensate News Publishers
item.description: The bill aims to compensate struggling news organizations, and follows similar moves by Europe and Australia.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Google’s offices in Kitchener, Ontario, in 2020.

item.title: ‘Sitting at Home and Trembling.’ A Town Emerges After a Russian Retreat.
item.description: A local official said he was detained and interrogated by the Russians, and described what he called mock executions.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Ukrainian Territorial Defense Forces delivering humanitarian aid to civilians in the village of Nova Basan, outside Kyiv, on Monday.

item.title: What Are War Crimes, and How Are They Prosecuted?
item.description: World leaders have vowed to hold President Vladimir V. Putin responsible for any atrocities by Russian forces. Past experience shows such cases take years to build and prosecute.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Iryna Venediktova, Ukraine’s prosecutor general, showed photographs documenting potential war crimes since the start of the war, during an interview in Lviv last month.

item.title: Shanghai defends separating infected children from uninfected parents.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: A line for mass testing in a lockdown area in Shanghai, China, on Monday. The city is battling its worst outbreak since the pandemic began, having logged more than 70,000 cases since the Omicron variant erupted last month.

item.title: Western Officials Condemn Reports of ‘Massacre’ by Military in Central Mali
item.description: The State Department and the French foreign ministry said they were alarmed at reports of deaths caused by the Malian armed forces and their allies — Russian mercenaries with the Wagner Group.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: A French soldier watches a Malian military unit arriving at Timbuktu airport, hours before the French handed over a military base to the Malian army in December.

item.title: Russia Shifts Focus of Ukraine War East as Putin Looks for a Victory
item.description: Having failed to score a quick triumph, Russia is shifting its attention to the contested breakaway enclaves, in Ukraine’s East. It is also shelling large cities to keep enemy forces from the expected new areas of battle.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: Evacuating from a residential area in Kharkiv that has been under continued bombing on Monday.

item.title: Images of Russian Atrocities Push West Toward Tougher Sanctions
item.description: President Biden called for Vladimir Putin to face trial for war crimes, and European officials will meet to consider possibly banning some Russian energy imports.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media shows President Vladimir V. Putin meeting with Deputy Prime Minister Yuri Borisov at the Kremlin on Monday.

item.title: Peru’s President Lifts Curfew That Shut Down Capital to Curb Protests
item.description: President Pedro Castillo had banned Lima residents from leaving their homes for nearly 24 hours, raising concerns among human rights groups and critics, but demonstrations continued after he backtracked.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj

item.title: Zelensky Accuses Russia of War Crimes, Criticizes U.N.’s Inaction
item.description: In a blistering address to the United Nations Security Council, Ukraine’s president asked what use the body was if it would not intervene to stop a war of aggression.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine speaks via remote video link during a meeting of the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday.

item.title: Video Captures Russian Forces Firing on Ukrainian Cyclist in Bucha
item.description: Chilling aerial video from Ukraine adds to the evidence of Russian atrocities against civilians and undercuts their denials of wrongdoing.
item.dc:creator: Malachy Browne and Dmitriy Khavin

item.title: At Least 200 Feared Dead in Apartments Hit by Russia, Officials Say
item.description: After Russian forces withdrew from Borodyanka, a commuter town near Ukraine’s capital, families are searching the rubble for bodies.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: As many as 200 people are missing and presumed dead under the rubble of Borodyanka, a commuter town not far from the capital, Kyiv.

item.title: The F.D.A. Suspends Use of Glaxo Antibody Drug in the U.S.
item.description: Manufacturers said lab testing revealed that the authorized dosage of the drug was not sufficiently potent against BA.2.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: A Covid testing site in Manhattan in March.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Zelensky Addressed the U.N.
item.description: Plus a change in Shanghai’s controversial family Covid policy and the tense build-up to the French presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky addresses the United Nations (UN) Security Council via video link on April 05, 2022 in New York City.

item.title: Britain’s National Health Service Expands Its List of Covid Symptoms
item.description: The National Health Service’s description of the disease now aligns more closely with that of the U.S. C.D.C.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Niki Kitsantonis

item.title: Hackers’ Fake Claims of Ukrainian Surrender Aren’t Fooling Anyone. So What’s Their Goal?
item.description: Experts say the hackers’ intentions might not be to actually trick anyone, but to erode confidence in Ukrainian media outlets and institutions.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in Irpin last week. Since Russia’s invasion began, hackers have repeatedly broken into the social media accounts and broadcasting systems of trusted information sources in Ukraine.

item.title: How America Watches for a Nuclear Strike
item.description: Hundreds of satellites and spacecraft are keeping an eye on Russia’s nuclear forces from above. So far, they haven’t seen much to worry about.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:description: In 2020, a rehearsal for a military parade in Moscow featured an RS-24 Yars, a Russian strategic nuclear missile.

item.title: Stolen Darwin Notebooks, Missing for Decades, Are Returned
item.description: The two notebooks were anonymously returned to the Cambridge University Library 22 years after they went missing. A note addressed to the librarian read: “Happy Easter.”
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: One of the returned notebooks included Charles Darwin’s famous “tree of life” drawing, which maps out how related species could diverge from a common ancestor.

item.title: E.P.A. to Propose Restrictions on Asbestos
item.description: The agency aims to ban the manufacturing and import of a type of asbestos that is used in brake pads, gaskets and other automotive products and is linked to cancer.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Workers removed asbestos-laden debris exposed by the Tubbs Fire in Santa Rosa, Calif., in 2017.

item.title: Zelensky Vilifies Russia Over Atrocities: ‘They Killed Entire Families’
item.description: The Ukrainian president delivered one of his most forceful denunciations of the invasion in a live video speech to the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine speaking on a video feed to the United Nations Security Council in New York on Tuesday.

item.title: Zelensky to Speak at U.N. Security Council Meeting on Russia
item.description: Mr. Zelensky was expected to make the case that Russian forces have committed war crimes, as evidence emerges of civilian killings in the suburbs of Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan and Andrés R. Martínez
item.media:description: A meeting of the United Nations Security Council at the organization’s headquarters in New York, last week.

item.title: How Can the World Respond to Russian Atrocities? Weapons and Sanctions
item.description: How can the world respond to Russian atrocities?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction in Bucha, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Lack of Hydrogen and Helium Led to Fewer Weather Surveying Balloon Trips
item.description: Disruptions to supplies of hydrogen and helium have led the National Weather Service to cancel routine launches at some sites.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: A meteorologist at the National Weather Service’s Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Okla., prepared a weather balloon for release in 2019.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Responses to evidence of Russian atrocities in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Remnants of vehicles on the road in Bucha, on Sunday.

item.title: South Africa lifts its Covid ‘state of disaster’ after two years.
item.description: Public health measures imposed under the declaration have often been strict, including bans on alcohol sales and certain types of clothing.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Walking past an informative graffiti art work educating local Soweto residents about the dangers of the coronavirus, Johannesburg, in November.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: The Fallout from Bucha
item.description: President Biden called the atrocity a “war crime.”
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Sri Lanka Protesters Call for President to Resign After Cabinet Shuffle
item.description: The country’s Rajapaksa dynasty is facing its toughest challenge yet as protesters demand that the president step down amid a devastating economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Emily Schmall
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students and other residents protesting the ongoing fuel and economic crisis at Independence Square in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Monday.

item.title: With a Neutral Stance on Ukraine, Viktor Orban Pulled in Voters
item.description: The Hungarian prime minister’s party also made a strong showing in Sunday’s election, though independent observers said the vote was tilted in the ruling party’s favor.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A screen showing Prime Minister Viktor Orban speaking to supporters on Sunday after the announcement of partial results in parliamentary elections in Budapest.

item.title: Atrocities in Bucha Complicate Russia-Ukraine Peace Talks
item.description: It was unclear what effect the killing of civilians outside Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, would have on negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Widespread destruction across Bucha on Sunday.

item.title: Rwandan Court Declines to Extend Sentence for Paul Rusesabagina
item.description: Mr. Rusesabagina, who inspired the movie “Hotel Rwanda” and later lived in exile in the United States, had been given a 25-year term in a case condemned by human-rights groups.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Paul Rusesabagina spoke to lawyers as he attended a hearing in Kigali, Rwanda, in February 2021.

item.title: Stopping Climate Change Is Doable, but Time Is Short, U.N. Panel Warns
item.description: A major new scientific report offers a road map for how countries can limit global warming, but warns that the margin for error is vanishingly small.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: Gas and flares emitted from the oil fields of Umm Qasr port near Iraq’s southern port city of Basra, in February.

item.title: 5 Takeaways From the U.N. Report on Limiting Global Warming
item.description: Current pledges to cut emissions, even if nations follow through on them, won’t stop temperatures from rising to risky new levels.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: A flooded street in Lismore, Australia, last month.

item.title: Some easyJet flights are canceled after workers test positive, and other developments.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: EasyJet and British Airways have each canceled flights recently because of coronavirus-related staff shortages.

item.title: Carrie Lam, racked by Covid failures, won’t seek a new term to lead Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Tiffany May
item.media:description: Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam during a news conference in Hong Kong, on Monday.

item.title: Zelensky Blasts Merkel and Sarkozy for Denying Ukraine NATO Membership
item.description: In a video address, he said that NATO’s decision in 2008 not to give Ukraine a path to membership helped lead to atrocities by Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany in Berlin last year. Ms. Merkel said via a spokeswoman that she stood “by her decisions” in 2008.

item.title: Senators Propose Cutting Global Vaccine Funding in Covid Package
item.description: The $10 billion package does not include funds for the global vaccination effort, frustrating some Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane, Alexandra E. Petri and Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: A health care worker administering Covid vaccines to students in Chitungwiza, Zimbabwe, last week.

item.title: Putin’s European allies
item.description: The fight between democracy and autocracy is happening not only in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: “Onwards Ukraine,” a mural in Paris by the street artist Seth.

item.title: Taiwan relaxes its quarantine measures even as it confronts an outbreak.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Residents wearing masks in Taipei, Taiwan, last month.

item.title: China deploys 2,000 military medics and 10,000 medical workers to Shanghai.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:description: Medical workers in Nanchang, Jiangxi Province, China, boarding a train to Shanghai on Sunday.

item.title: Bristling Against the West, China Rallies Domestic Sympathy for Russia
item.description: China’s Communist Party is mounting an ideological campaign aimed at officials and students. The message: The country will not turn its back on Russia.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Host photo agency/RIA Novosti, via Getty Images
item.media:description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in 2015 at a parade in Moscow commemorating the end of World War II.

item.title: The Transfixing Beauty of Starling Murmurations
item.description: Each spring and autumn, the skies in southern Denmark come to life with the swirling displays of hundreds of thousands of starlings, an event known locally as “sort sol.”
item.dc:creator: Søren Solkær
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: Women in Saudi Arabia Add a First: An Auto Rally
item.description: Just years after women could legally drive there, the Rally Jameel celebrates a new first.
item.dc:creator: Lyn Woodward
item.media:description: The all-women Rally Jameel in Saudi Arabia last month covered nearly 690 miles, more than 200 of them off-road.

item.title: French Election Opens Up as Marine Le Pen Surges
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron’s belated entry into the campaign and his focus on Ukraine have left him vulnerable to a strong challenge from the right.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France at a campaign rally on Saturday on the outskirts of Paris.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Reports of Russian atrocities.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Widespread destruction could be seen across Bucha, Ukraine, a suburb northwest of Kyiv where Russian forces recently withdrew.

item.title: Carrie Lam, Hong Kong’s Leader, Won’t Seek Second Term
item.description: Carrie Lam, the territory’s chief executive, said Monday that she would not seek a second term. Her tenure was marked by protests, a contentious law and a devastating Covid outbreak.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Tiffany May
item.media:description: Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam during a news conference in Hong Kong, on Monday.

item.title: President Volodymyr Zelensky Gives Emotional Speech at the Grammys
item.description: The Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelensky, made a plea for support before John Legend performed, sharing the stage with a poet and a singer from Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Julia Jacobs
item.media:description: “Our children draw swooping rockets, not shooting stars,” Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukrainian president, said in video that was broadcast during the Grammys on Sunday night.

item.title: Pro-Putin Leaders in Hungary and Serbia Set to Win Re-election
item.description: Viktor Orban declared victory, and Serbia’s Aleksandar Vucic seemed likely to emerge on top. Both pledged to stay out of Russia’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Benjamin Novak
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban after declaring victory on Sunday in Budapest, Hungary.
